holdings.text: The Custodian is entitled to entertain the claim of the holder of a money decree against the evacuee for satisfaction of his dues out of the assets vested in the Custodian under section 7 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act by virtue of powers under section 10(2)(n).

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian held that he had nosuch power, and the Custodian General agreed with him. Section 10 of the Act deals with the powers and duties of the Custodian generally. By sub-s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of section 10(1) general powers for administration, section 10(2)(n) specific power to pay entitled persons, limited vesting under sections 7-8, section 17 bars court execution but not Custodian duty to pay debts, rejection of contrary arguments.

holdings.text: The expression 'any other person' in section 10(2)(n) is not to be construed ejusdem generis with 'evacuee' or 'any member of his family' as no genus or category is indicated.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the expression any other person in cl. n must be construed ejusdem generis with evacuee or ,.any member of his family has, in our judgment, noforce. The rule of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule of ejusdem generis applies only where specific words indicate a genus; here preceding words do not form a category limiting the general phrase.

holdings.text: Section 10(2)(n) confers upon the Custodian power coupled with a duty to pay sums to entitled persons out of evacuee funds.

anchor.surface_text: The clause is intended to confer upon the Custodian power coupled with a duty to pay to the evacuee or to any member of his family or to any other person as in

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of clause indicates mandatory obligation tied to opinion of entitlement for administration purposes.

holdings.text: Vesting of evacuee property in Custodian under sections 7 and 8 is only for purposes of the Act; Custodian holds as agent bound to administer including satisfaction of debts.

anchor.surface_text: But the vesting of the property in the Custodian is for the purposes of the Act i.e. for administration and management. By the vesting for purposes of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory vesting limited to administration and management; Custodian not absolute owner but fiduciary for evacuee.

holdings.text: Section 17 bars proceedings in execution against vested evacuee property by courts or authorities but does not relieve Custodian of obligation to satisfy evacuee's debts.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 17 1  of the Act as amended by Act 22 of 1951 with retrospective operation it was provided that Save as otherwise

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section excludes court processes to preserve administration but scheme of Act requires Custodian to discharge obligations.

holdings.text: Custodian invested with power under section 10 to pay debts and discharge liabilities of evacuee as part of securing, administering, preserving and managing property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms and scheme of section 10(1) and illustrative clauses (e.g., carry business, repairs, legal proceedings, compromise) imply power and duty to pay valid claims.

holdings.text: Amendment to section 10(2)(m) deleting debt payment provision and deletion of Rule 22 do not restrict Custodian's power under section 10(2)(n) or general powers under section 10(1).

anchor.surface_text: counsel for the Custodian relies upon the terms of s. 10 2   m  as they originally stood before they were amended by Act 91 of 1956 and the deletion of Rule 22

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses in section 10(2) illustrative and not mutually exclusive; power derives from multiple sources unaffected by specific deletions.

holdings.text: Custodian must form opinion on genuineness of claims judicially and not arbitrarily; decree not conclusive but prima facie supports entitlement.

anchor.surface_text: The decree of a civil or revenue court or an order of any other authority is, it must be observed, not decisive of the validity or admissibility of the claim

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'in the opinion of the Custodian' requires judicial determination; normal to pay on valid decree unless disproved.

anchor.surface_text: As the Tribunals below have determined the claim raised before them only on the question of jurisdiction to entertain it and number on the merits, we are unable to pass any effective order in favour of the appellant. The orders passed by the Custodian and the Cus-todian General must therefore be set aside and the proceeding remanded to the Custodian to determine the question whether in the opinion of the Custodian the appellant is entitled to any sum of money out of the funds in his possession

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; orders of Custodian and Custodian General set aside; proceedings remanded to Custodian to decide claim on merits regarding jurisdiction to pay decree-holder from evacuee property
